Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2013 01:47PM ketch wrote: Just clicked on here. LE is giving me fits and I usually do not get on this thread,but figured I might pick up some pointers. After I read Purple's post, I went back to check the name thinking during a groggy night I may have posted it! I've been attempting to sleep on my back as well due to shoulder pain. I have truncal LE. So, that aggravates my shoulder pain, too. Today, I got the results of my yearly full body bone scan. No cancer on anything!!!! But, it did show arthritis in my collarbone area. The doctor said it probably contributed to the shoulder pain.My collarbones do not hurt at all & the doctor said it was an odd place for arthritis to show up in someone who'd not been in a wreck or someone who'd not been a prizefighter. Between cancer & LE, arthritis ain't a big deal!! I'll figure out how not to roll over.
Posts.Title: Shoulder issues ? purple32 ketch

Posts.Content: ketch wrote: At the suggestion of the PT, I got my hot tub cleaned out and ready. I did not cut the heat on as it is plenty hot enough here to heat the water right now. I've been getting in it everyday, mostly just sitting and doing the self massage. It's working!! I can see changes already just after a few days! The PT said water & swimming were the best things I could do. No swimming pool, but myhot tub/playpool is working! Posts.Title: SOME SUCCESS! ketch Binney4

Posts.Content: ketch wrote: Just got back from the radiologist. Biopsy showed DCIS. That is all I heard along with her telling me  what DCIS was, etc. I thought I asked all the right questions and such, and luckily I got my pathology report. It reads: Duct carcinoma in situ, intermediate grade with microfoci of invasive mammary carcinoma.Single largest of focus of invasivecarcinoma measures 3.1 milli, no lymphovascular or perineural invasion identified, lobular carcinoma in situ While in there, all I heard was DCIS. Now I have the microfoci of invasive cancer measuring 3.1 millimeters. Invasvie cancer?? this is different from DCIS, right? My husband said she mentioned it but i did not focus on that. Dx 12/4/2011, ILC, Stage 0, Grade 2, 0/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 1/12/2012 Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 2/8/2012 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 7/1/2012 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 2/14/2013 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Results=cancer ketch ketch

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 03:40PM ketch wrote: That is what I thought. Tommy told me she mentioned it, but I guess I was still digesting the DCIS. Thank goodness, I knew to ask for the path report. I'm at a loss what to do now. They've set up an MRI for Tuesday & a surgical consult for Wednesday. Even though the surgeon is well respected, he is a general surgeon. I do not want someone taking out a gallbladder int he morning operating on mybreast at lunch. I want a specialist. I am 2 hours from Atlanta (where my late aunt went to a BS who is a PS & Surgical onco) and 3 hours from Charleston, where the breast clinic is. I dont know where to go or turn at this point. My GP, who is also my neighbor, told me that they may want to do radiation first, or removed the place and do a masectomy later on. He told me if given the choice to do a mesectomy. I'd already decided on that. I watch my aunt die with BC & took care of her. SHe had 1 breast removed, then 10 years later cancer came back in the other one... and it came back with a vengence. I am 52, so I am not ready to give into this and want to lower any chance I can of spreading or coming back.
Posts.Title: Results=cancer ketch ketch

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 03:43PM ketch wrote: I checked the Back Max $129-249. The more expensive one has a place for your arms so theydo not hang off. I already use a wedge pillow at night or wind up in the recliner. So, I'm going to wait on this purchase right now. Luckily, I have a huge Amazon gift card,, so if this works out for others, I may give it a try later on. This might be good for Stage 2, as well.
Posts.Title: Shoulder issues ? purple32 ketch

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2014 01:44AM ketch wrote: I've had a difficult time getting any of my doctors to take the lymphedema seriously. My PS knows and has seen it at its worse--he acknowledges it, at least. The breast surgeon just can't believe I have it with only 3 removed on the right and 4 on the left. He's also seen it at its worst. Family doctor and oncologist seem to ignore it.  I just had a horrible bout of cellulitus, too. The infectious disease doctor told me anyone could get cellulitus. I know they can, but mine stemmed directly from the lymphedema. It is frustrating.

Posts.Title: Have trouble getting your Doctors to understand your Lymphedema? Meggy glennie19

Posts.Content: ketch wrote: I had 9 nodes removed on left, 3 on right (thankfully all were clean.) My surgery was Jan. 12th. This may be normal healing & may not. So I need some help. Most time during the day, I am fine. Some days though, it feels like a tennis ball ball is under my skin about 3 inches down from my underarm. The right side is the worst, where the 9 nodes were removed. No sign of seromas, just the feeling of a ball, a painful on, at that. |Same on the right side, but not as bad. This worsens at night. I tend to side sleep. I will roll to my side & awake in pain. My ribs on my left side are terribly sore most of the time regardless of sleep position. It feels like I've been punched hard! It seems to cramp.I can't really tell if it is swollen since I can feel my ribs. The tennis ball feeling does feel swollen, but not thr rib. No arm/hand swelling at all. Is the Lymphdema? Or, am I still just healing? Posts.Title: under arm & ribs---help? ketch Cats134

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2014 01:16AM ketch wrote: I have truncal LE and I have a good deal of pain with my LE. I also have a stiff neck at times, but mine is mostly in my shoulder, underneath my arms and my foobs. It also sometimes, esp when I walk a distance, in my shoulder blade area. The fluid moves around...just not in the direction it should! SO to answer you, and I am far from an expert (there's a ton of knowledge on these boards and I'm not one of them), it sounds like you're having truncal LE problems, too.
Posts.Title: Is this a normal pain that comes with lymph edema? gginna FireKracker

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2013 08:26PM ketch wrote: I don't care what the LE therapist told you....I am in the same boat. My left shoulder was bummed up a few years back. I deal with LE everyday, but I have "flares" 1-2 per month. When it flares, my mobility is affected & it hurts. My LE is truncal affecting both shoulders & now it seems to be moving into my left leg! I had a flare up last week, a bad one. And, I can feel it starting back again tonight. I am trying the brushing and hoping that is just moving the fluid around some. So far, nothing much has helped me.
Posts.Title: shoulder mobility PersonalTrainer PersonalTrainer

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 04:06AM ketch wrote: I have ILC, 1cm, clean nodes & good numbers, but the oncologist told me that I was on the cusp of whether to do chemo or not. I was expecting not to have to do anything other than a pill. He said due to my age (52), he would recommend the chemo. My age again is on the cusp. He said his job was to keep me alive till a ripe old age and he did not want to look back 5-10 years down the road and wish we'd done chemo. That hit home as I had a beloved  aunt diagnosed at 57. She never wanted chemo, had 1 node positive, took tamoxifen and another drug afterwards. The cancer came back at 68 and she died quickly thereafter, but did do radiation this time, something she said she would never do. I took care of her during the last months and while she never mentioned wishing that she'd done chemo, I always wondered if it would have made a difference. I stated that once I found out I had BC. So when the doctor mentioned that, I knew I would have it. Scheduled to start, next week. I do not want it, but I do not want to wish later on that I had.
Posts.Title: Deciding whether to do chemo firstcall Bluebird-DE

Posts.Content: ketch wrote: I'm tired. Finished chemo in May, so far, so good. I've been going to excersise regularly. Thankfully, my hospital offered cancer rehab similar to heart rehab. That has helped me tremendously. JUst returned from a 10 day vacation that was great and was beginning to feel normal again. Then, it hit. Last Wednesday, I was tired. Thinking I'd overdone it on Tuesday, I just rested that day. I skipped excersise Friday as I was too tired and slept about 15 hours. I was doing so well, then it's like I went back about 2-3 months. I do take thyroid meds for hypothyroidism, so I am wondering if that is the problem or if it is the effects from chemo all these months later?? I have my scheduled onco appt. in 2 weeks.
